data.author: Frankie963
data.content: Several major companies associated with billionaire fortunes have at least 50% of their shares or voting rights held in trusts, foundations, or family-controlled holding companies. These structures are often used to ensure long-term control, manage succession, and handle philanthropic donations. Tata Sons (Tata Group): The promoter holding company of the Tata Group, which controls companies like Tata Motors and Tata Steel, has approximately 50% or more of its share capital held by two trusts: Sir Dorabji Tata Trust and Sir Ratan Tata Trust. Roche Group: Descendants of the founding Hoffmann and Oeri families hold slightly more than 50% of the voting shares in this Swiss healthcare giant. Robert Bosch GmbH: The German automotive supplier and industrial giant has 92% of its share capital held by Robert Bosch Stiftung GmbH (a charitable foundation). Cargill Inc.: The world's largest privately held company is owned by the Cargill and MacMillan families, who hold roughly 85% of the company, often managed through family trusts. Auchan Group: The French retailing group is controlled by the Mulliez family, who hold roughly 95% of the company. Louis Dreyfus Company: The agricultural commodity company is primarily owned by the Louis-Dreyfus family, who hold approximately 96% of the company. Mars Incorporated: The candy and pet food conglomerate is 100% owned by the Mars family, with management of ownership often tied to trusts. Aldi Group: The Albrecht family controls 100% of the Aldi retail group, split between trusts. Key Takeaways regarding Trust Ownership: Legal Structure: A trust often holds legal ownership of shares for the benefit of family members (beneficiaries). Control vs. Equity: In some cases, such as Roche, the trust may control over 50% of the votes, while holding less than 10% of the total capital. Philanthropic Trusts: Billionaires, including Bill Gates (via the Gates Foundation Trust) and Warren Buffett, use trusts to manage large blocks of company stock (like Berkshire Hathaway) for philanthropic purposes.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: A CEO leaving a considerable amount of shares in a trust for employees and their families is typically structured as an Employee Ownership Trust (EOT) or an Employee Benefit Trust (EBT). This strategy allows the CEO to transition ownership while providing, rewarding, and incentivising staff, often with significant tax advantages. Here is an analysis of this approach based on current practices and regulations: 1. Structure of the Trust Employee Ownership Trust (EOT): A type of EBT where the trust holds a controlling stake (more than 50%) in the company on behalf of all employees. It is often used to ensure the company remains independent and to maintain its culture. Employee Benefit Trust (EBT): A more flexible trust that can be used to hold shares for distribution to specific employees or groups, or to hold shares to satisfy future share options. 2. Benefits to Employees and Families Long-Term Value Creation: Employees benefit from the growth of the company, often receiving dividends or bonuses (up to £3,600 per year per employee, tax-free in the UK, if qualifying conditions are met). No Direct Cost: Employees generally do not have to pay for the shares themselves; the trust holds them on their behalf. Security and Stability: EOTs help in preserving the company's independence and preventing a hostile takeover. Incentivisation: A share in the company’s success acts as a strong motivator for employee engagement and retention. 3. Advantages for the CEO Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Exemption: In the UK, if a controlling interest (more than 50%) is sold to an EOT, the seller can benefit from a 0% capital gains tax rate. Succession Planning: It provides a clean, tax-efficient exit strategy, allowing the CEO to leave behind a stable company. Legacy Preservation: The trust structure keeps the company intact, ensuring the legacy of the founder and the company’s culture continues. 4. Key Considerations and Risks Valuation Requirements: The shares must be sold to the EOT at their full market value, which requires an independent valuation. Funding the Trust: Because the trust often lacks funds, it is common for the seller (CEO) to be paid via a "vendor loan note," where the company uses future profits to pay for the shares over several years. Complex Rules: As of the Autumn Budget 2024, there are stricter rules for EOTs, including limitations on former owners controlling the trust and new residency requirements for trustees. Employee Performance Connection: In a 100% employee-owned company, it can be difficult to differentiate incentives for senior staff compared to the rest of the employees. Real-World Examples John Lewis Partnership: The classic example of a "John Lewis model," where all employees are beneficiaries of the trust. Richer Sounds: The founder transferred controlling ownership to an EOT to reward employees and secure the future. Boosst Financial Planning: The founders sold 100% of their shares to an EOT to protect the

data.content: Would like to Add to Shrewed_mole Combined Summary of All Administrator Reports (2024–2025) 🏢 Company Background • 	Name: LP Realisations Limited (formerly Lake Parime Limited) • 	Company No.: 11773819 • 	Sector: High‑performance computing, data‑centre infrastructure, and IT hardware • 	Administrators: Interpath Advisory • 	Administration Start: 2023 • 	Dissolution Process Initiated: January  2025 Why the Company Entered Administration Across the filings, the administrators outline a consistent picture: 1. Severe Financial Distress - The company was unable to meet its liabilities as they fell due. - Cashflow pressures were significant due to high capital expenditure and operating costs typical of compute‑intensive infrastructure businesses. 2. Asset‑Heavy Business Model - The company invested heavily in specialised computing hardware and data‑centre equipment. - These assets depreciated quickly and required substantial ongoing energy and hosting costs. 3. Funding & Market Conditions - The company had been backed by the UK Government’s Future Fund, indicating it relied on external investment to scale. - Market volatility in energy‑intensive computing (including HPC and blockchain‑adjacent workloads) likely contributed to instability. What the Administrators Did (Across All Reports) 1. Secured and Realised Assets The administrators: - Took control of the company’s data‑centre equipment, servers, and related infrastructure. - Marketed and sold assets where possible to generate returns for creditors. - Managed contracts, leases, and any recoverable receivables. Investigated Company Affairs Standard statutory investigations were carried out, including: • 	Director conduct • 	Transactions prior to insolvency • 	Creditor claims • 	Contractual obligations No unusual or exceptional findings are mentioned in the filings. Managed Creditor Claims - Preferential, secured, and unsecured creditor classes were identified. - Claims were reviewed and adjudicated. - The reports indicate limited returns for unsecured creditors due to the company’s asset profile. 💷 Financial Outcome (High‑Level) While the filings contain detailed numbers, the combined picture is: - Asset realisations were modest relative to liabilities. - Secured creditors received the majority of recoveries. - Unsecured creditors are expected to receive little or no dividend. - The company had no viable route to rescue, leading to dissolution. 🏁 Final Stage: Move to Dissolution (Jan 2025) The final filing — Notice of Move from Administration to Dissolution — confirms: - The administration has achieved its statutory purpose. - No further asset realisations are expected. - The company will be dissolved after the notice period. - This marks the end of the insolvency process. 📚 Sources - Companies House filing history for LP Realisations Limited, including: - Administrator’s Pr

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Lake Parime Ltd went into administration in early 2023, with Ed Boyle and Will Wright appointed as joint administrators, meaning leadership changed from its original directors, who included founder Sath Ganesarajah, CEO Alexander Siedes, Creative Director John Davies, and COO Nimesh Mistry (who joined from Barclays). Key Individuals & Roles (Before Administration): Sath Ganesarajah: Founder. Alexander Siedes: CEO & Board Member. Nimesh Mistry: COO, joined from Barclays. John Davies: Creative Director. Paul Shepherdson: Business Development Director. Current Status: Administration: The company entered administration in January 2023, with Interpath Advisory handling the process. Company Name Change: The entity is now listed as LP REALISATIONS LIMITED, with its registered office address updated in February 2023. In Summary: While specific directors led Lake Parime, the company's operations were taken over by administrators, leading to significant changes in its structure and management, as reflected in its filing history.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Bluebird Executive Director and Interim CEO Aidan Bishop said, "I am very pleased with the progress of discussions in the Philippines which are looking very positive and will enable, if successfully completed, Bluebird to maintain an ongoing exposure with zero future cash commitments. On a personal level, I embarked some time ago on a journey to understand and learn about bitcoin. I am convinced that we are witnessing a tectonic shift in global markets and that bitcoin will reshape the landscape of financial markets on every level. By adopting a 'gold plus a digital gold' strategy, it offers the Company an opportunity to turn the page and look to the future and seek to attract a new type of shareholder. Under the leadership of a new CEO, once identified, it is my sincere hope that Bluebird will finally realise its ambitions for which it was initially established for." Sath Ganesarajah, 43, British Sath is a seasoned entrepreneur and investor with deep expertise in crypto assets and institutional capital markets. He first bought Bitcoin in 2017 and has since advised several global hedge funds and institutional investors on crypto strategy, digital asset fund structuring, and large-scale infrastructure deployment-supporting mandates totaling over US$1 billion in Assets Under Management (AUM). He is the founder and CEO of The BE Company, a clean energy and AI infrastructure business with operations in the UK, US, and Canada. Across multiple ventures, he has developed and operated over 50MW of digital infrastructure, including immersion-cooled compute and modular clean energy projects.  Earlier in his career, Sath held senior trading and structuring roles at Morgan Stanley, Citi, and Credit Suisse, specialising in structured credit and emerging markets. The Board will work together with a view to expediting the appointment of a new CEO by the end of July with several candidates presently in the frame whom will be tasked with spearheading Bluebird's UK first approach of physical Gold + "digital gold" investing strategy. Mr Ganesarajah commented:  "Bluebird has the right ingredients-hard assets, public market access, and a clean slate. My ambition is to help shape Bluebird into a £1 billion company over the coming cycle."

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Crypto faces immediate industry consolidation as market downturn exposes weak business models, according to Bullish CEO Tom Farley. Bitcoin's 45% decline from its October 2025 peak of $126,100 to approximately $69,400 is accelerating a shakeout that should have occurred years earlier. Farley, who previously served as president of the New York Stock Exchange, told CNBC that inflated valuations kept unrealistic expectations alive until now. "The same thing is going to happen starting right now in crypto," Farley said during his Friday interview. He witnessed similar consolidation patterns in the exchange sector during his NYSE tenure. Companies with $10 million in revenue and no growth were still demanding $200 million valuations, according to Farley. That era of over-optimistic pricing is ending as the market correction washes away what he called "false optimism." "People are going to realize they don't have businesses, they have products, and they need to merge up, and they need to scale, and that is going to happen," Farley said. The consolidation should have started one to two years ago but was delayed by unrealistic 2020-era valuation expectations. The process will involve larger companies acquiring smaller, underperforming projects across the crypto market. This absorption will likely lead to significant layoffs, internal reorganizations, and industry-wide restructuring. Venture capital firms have already become more selective with crypto investments as the market matures. Investment decisions now focus on scalable, sustainable projects rather than speculative ventures, according to industry sources. Farley believes surviving companies must transition from being "features" to becoming "institutional, compliant, and respected." The shift represents a move away from what he described as "chasing frog coins and 100x use" toward more substantial on-chain finance. Even traditional financial institutions like the NYSE have shown interest in blockchain systems for stock trading, suggesting the underlying technology has staying power despite individual project failures. This institutional endorsement indicates blockchain infrastructure is becoming a fixture of modern global finance. The current market downturn acts as a filter, forcing companies to prove long-term viability to attract buyers or survive independently. The result will likely be a crypto industry that resembles traditional finance, with a handful of large, heavily regulated companies providing most infrastructure. For firms that adapt during this transition, consolidation offers a chance to become legitimate long-term players in what Farley sees as an increasingly professional global market. The transformation marks the end of what he characterized as the industry's "wild west" phase. Bullish CEO Tom Farley says crypto faces immediate industry consolidation - Originally published on Technobez

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: BMV Blue Print Gold Reserve • Streaming contracts and physical holdings secure permanence. • Land & infrastructure assets strengthen the balance sheet with recurring lease income. • Collateral strength provides downside resilience and credit efficiency. The Bridge • Gold provides permanence; bitcoin provides progress. • Together, they create a treasury that is both resilient and compounding. Bitcoin Rail • All inflows systematically converted into bitcoin under custody. • Enhances liquidity, settlement, and compounding power. • Complements gold, never replaces it. Capital Structure Advantage • Equity trades as a clean bitcoin proxy. • Gold is ring-fenced for creditors, reducing financing costs. • Dual-asset symmetry ensures balance across cycles. The Treasury Flywheel The Flywheel turns capital into contracts, contracts into bitcoin, and bitcoin into shareholder value — quarter after quarter. Why Streaming Wins Contract-backed: predictable inflows, enforceable terms. Capital-light: exposure without operational drag. Scalable: multiple counterparties without consolidation risk. NAV-accretive: uplift recorded at signing, compounded through treasury conversion. Gold streaming secures permanence. Bitcoin streaming drives growth. Together, they power the Reserve & Rail model.

data.content: That's why he has bought in one of the best Metals derivative players in the world - Frank Amato The timing of BMV's plan seems to be on point ! Since the Company's Operational Update on 10 December 2025, BMV has experienced a marked increase in inbound interest relating to its gold streaming and treasury strategy. This includes engagement from counterparties exploring tokenised and digitally settled gold structures, as well as institutional and strategic participants seeking exposure through structured upstream arrangements spanning physical metal, derivative-linked flows, and tokenised formats. The Board believes this renewed interest reflects a broader crossover between digital asset infrastructure and physical gold, alongside evolving macro conditions. In particular, the Company notes the current interest-rate outlook and the potential rollback of certain US trade tariffs as factors that may act as catalysts for renewed risk appetite, providing structural tailwinds for gold-linked treasury and streaming strategies. The Board continues to believe that BMV's gold streaming and treasury model is well positioned to capture this demand in a disciplined and regulated manner.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: The convergence of gold streaming/mining and Bitcoin treasury strategies has emerged as a significant trend, with companies aiming to blend the "old safe haven" (physical gold) with "digital gold" (Bitcoin) to diversify reserves and hedge against inflation. This "hybrid" approach is gaining traction among resource developers and investment firms, particularly in the UK and through major stablecoin issuers. Key Players and Developments (As of early 2026): Tether: The stablecoin giant has aggressively moved into this space, holding over $300 million in gold royalty stocks by late 2025, including stakes in Elemental Altus Royalties, Versamet Royalties, and Metalla Royalty & Streaming. Tether also holds substantial gold reserves, with estimates reaching 80–116 metric tonnes, often utilizing its digital gold product XAUT. Bluebird Mining Ventures Ltd: A key player merging these strategies, Bluebird is a gold development company that has recently focused on "marrying its existing mining projects and expertise with the future that is 'digital gold' aka bitcoin". They are working on gold-streaming projects in Asia and Africa while investing in Bitcoin mining. Mendell Helium PLC: This company announced it is adopting a bitcoin treasury management policy and plans to use a loan facility secured by its bitcoin holdings to finance the acquisition of the Pick Lake deposit in Ontario, illustrating a direct link between bitcoin holdings and physical asset acquisition. Tap Global Group [LON:TAP]: Launched a "Bitcoin Treasury as a Service" (BTaaS) to help publicly listed companies, particularly in the UK, manage Bitcoin as a core treasury asset, with a focus on institutional-grade security for companies merging digital assets into their strategies. B HODL: A UK-based firm that has established a position as a Bitcoin treasury company, focusing on accumulating Bitcoin while also operating Lightning Network operations. Strategy and Market Context: "Digital Gold" Adoption: Similar to the MicroStrategy playbook, these companies often seek to hold Bitcoin as a long-term strategic reserve rather than for immediate cash flow, positioning themselves as future-focused. Diversification: The trend represents a move to diversify treasury holdings beyond just fiat currency, using both gold (for traditional stability) and Bitcoin (for high growth/digital scarcity). Funding Mechanism: Some companies are using Bitcoin loans to fund the acquisition of traditional physical mining assets. Market Position: As of early 2026, the strategy is facing volatility, with some Bitcoin treasury firms seeing their market capitalization drop below the value of their actual Bitcoin holdings. Gold and Bitcoin Correlation: Data from late 2025/early 2026 shows a 0.14 correlation between Bitcoin and gold, indicating that while they are often paired in portfolios, they can move independently. However, both are increasingly viewed as "debasement trades"—methods to protect against fiat c

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: That's why he has bought in one of the best Metals derivative players in the world - Frank Amato The timing of BMV's plan seems to be on point ! Since the Company's Operational Update on 10 December 2025, BMV has experienced a marked increase in inbound interest relating to its gold streaming and treasury strategy. This includes engagement from counterparties exploring tokenised and digitally settled gold structures, as well as institutional and strategic participants seeking exposure through structured upstream arrangements spanning physical metal, derivative-linked flows, and tokenised formats. The Board believes this renewed interest reflects a broader crossover between digital asset infrastructure and physical gold, alongside evolving macro conditions. In particular, the Company notes the current interest-rate outlook and the potential rollback of certain US trade tariffs as factors that may act as catalysts for renewed risk appetite, providing structural tailwinds for gold-linked treasury and streaming strategies. The Board continues to believe that BMV's gold streaming and treasury model is well positioned to capture this demand in a disciplined and regulated manner.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Components of Institutional Deployment Upfront Financing: A significant, often upfront payment is made to the miner in exchange for a percentage of future production at a fixed, discounted price. Operational Control: While streaming companies do not operate the mines, they may place restrictions or covenants on the operator to protect the investment. Long-Term Focus: Institutions often hold these positions for over three years as part of a long-term strategy to gain exposure to gold while avoiding the high capital expenditures and operational risks of direct mining. Institutional Players The market is dominated by large players like Franco-Nevada, Royal Gold, and Sandstorm, alongside major institutional investors seeking to add "safer" gold exposure compared to direct equity. BlueBird are using Bitcoin in what is a 1 off unique Treasury platform - The reason why it must have taken so long for the prospectus to be approved by the FCA due to it's complex nature - legal and compliance etc! The balance sheet is now in a healthy and robust position with cash at hand and in trust - maybe this financial moving around was not a bad thing after all - I have a feeling in my waters that this will surprise many here as to what can transpire Shrewdie

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Institutional-grade deployment in gold streaming refers to the allocation of large-scale, professional capital into mining projects via streaming agreements that meet stringent risk, compliance, and structural standards. These investments are characterized by deep due diligence, secure legal structures, and high-quality counterparties (e.g., pension funds, insurance companies, major streaming companies). There are roughly 7760-767 million shares in the free float here You can remove an almost 700 million shares from the discounted share rise as they are held in trust - for employee's /contractors etc! So we only had just over 400 million shares on what was 1.2 billion ? If we get any incoming TR!'s with any big funds buying in (it's a pretty novel treasury platform and 1st mover advantage) expect the shares to be snapped up based on future events This has a potential target of up to As of early 2026, the sector is experiencing increased, "institutional-grade" capital deployment, aimed at supporting gold-streaming flows with enhanced control frameworks. Key Characteristics of Institutional-Grade Gold Streaming Asset Quality and Security: Deals are typically focused onTier 1 assets (high-grade, low-cost) with significant mine life, often involving large-scale operations. Rigorous Due Diligence: Institutional-grade deals require independently verified financial statements, rigorous risk controls, and strong governance from the mining operator. Risk Management: Investors use streaming to diversify across multiple mines, reducing exposure to single-asset failure. Structure: These agreements often act as non-dilutive financing for miners, allowing them to monetize by-product gold without giving up equity. Transparency and Compliance: These investments must meet high standards of transparency, with auditing, and legal, and regulatory compliance. Components of Institutional Deployment Upfront Financing: A significant, often upfront payment is made to the miner in exchange for a percentage of future production at a fixed, discounted price. Operational Control: While streaming companies do not operate the mines, they may place restrictions or covenants on the operator to protect the investment. Long-Term Focus: Institutions often hold these positions for over three years as part of a long-term strategy to gain exposure to gold while avoiding the high capital expenditures and operational risks of direct mining. Institutional Players The market is dominated by large players like Franco-Nevada, Royal Gold, and Sandstorm, alongside major institutional investors seeking to add "safer" gold exposure compared to direct equity. Recent Trends Basel III Impact: The classification of allocated physical gold as a Tier 1 High-Quality Liquid Asset (HQLA) has reinforced institutional interest in gold. Increased Activity: Increased deployment is expected, particularly as miners look to secure capital for development and expansion during tim

data.content: Components of Institutional Deployment Upfront Financing: A significant, often upfront payment is made to the miner in exchange for a percentage of future production at a fixed, discounted price. Operational Control: While streaming companies do not operate the mines, they may place restrictions or covenants on the operator to protect the investment. Long-Term Focus: Institutions often hold these positions for over three years as part of a long-term strategy to gain exposure to gold while avoiding the high capital expenditures and operational risks of direct mining. Institutional Players The market is dominated by large players like Franco-Nevada, Royal Gold, and Sandstorm, alongside major institutional investors seeking to add "safer" gold exposure compared to direct equity. data.author: Nowthewiser
data.content: @Frankie963 , on this proposed Employee Ownership Trust (EOT), the first question is: where is the funding coming from? If the plan relies on issuing more shares, that simply dilutes existing shareholders to create a structure that seems to benefit the directors rather than the owners. This is not how an investable company behaves. Before introducing schemes like this, the CEO should be able to demonstrate a real product and a credible business model. Right now, all we see are constant restructurings, no cash, no delivery, and endless promises. In my opinion, the pattern is starting to resemble a well‑constructed Ponzi‑style setup, where new shareholder money is needed just to keep the story alive. Based on my own experience and losses, I cannot recommend anyone put their money into this.

data.content: @Frankie963 , I’ve read the FCA correspondence and the  Grace Church's comments, but none of it changes the underlying reality. In my view, the company remains uninvestable. It has no meaningful cash to support the gold‑streaming strategy it keeps promoting, and the recently appointed non‑executive directors appear to add little beyond an attempt to create the impression of credibility. As someone who has personally lost money due to what I believe has been a pattern of misleading communication, I cannot in good conscience encourage anyone to invest further. People deserve transparency, and right now I don’t see it.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: Several major companies associated with billionaire fortunes have at least 50% of their shares or voting rights held in trusts, foundations, or family-controlled holding companies. These structures are often used to ensure long-term control, manage succession, and handle philanthropic donations. Tata Sons (Tata Group): The promoter holding company of the Tata Group, which controls companies like Tata Motors and Tata Steel, has approximately 50% or more of its share capital held by two trusts: Sir Dorabji Tata Trust and Sir Ratan Tata Trust. Roche Group: Descendants of the founding Hoffmann and Oeri families hold slightly more than 50% of the voting shares in this Swiss healthcare giant. Robert Bosch GmbH: The German automotive supplier and industrial giant has 92% of its share capital held by Robert Bosch Stiftung GmbH (a charitable foundation). Cargill Inc.: The world's largest privately held company is owned by the Cargill and MacMillan families, who hold roughly 85% of the company, often managed through family trusts. Auchan Group: The French retailing group is controlled by the Mulliez family, who hold roughly 95% of the company. Louis Dreyfus Company: The agricultural commodity company is primarily owned by the Louis-Dreyfus family, who hold approximately 96% of the company. Mars Incorporated: The candy and pet food conglomerate is 100% owned by the Mars family, with management of ownership often tied to trusts. Aldi Group: The Albrecht family controls 100% of the Aldi retail group, split between trusts. Key Takeaways regarding Trust Ownership: Legal Structure: A trust often holds legal ownership of shares for the benefit of family members (beneficiaries). Control vs. Equity: In some cases, such as Roche, the trust may control over 50% of the votes, while holding less than 10% of the total capital. Philanthropic Trusts: Billionaires, including Bill Gates (via the Gates Foundation Trust) and Warren Buffett, use trusts to manage large blocks of company stock (like Berkshire Hathaway) for philanthropic purposes.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: A CEO leaving a considerable amount of shares in a trust for employees and their families is typically structured as an Employee Ownership Trust (EOT) or an Employee Benefit Trust (EBT). This strategy allows the CEO to transition ownership while providing, rewarding, and incentivising staff, often with significant tax advantages. Here is an analysis of this approach based on current practices and regulations: 1. Structure of the Trust Employee Ownership Trust (EOT): A type of EBT where the trust holds a controlling stake (more than 50%) in the company on behalf of all employees. It is often used to ensure the company remains independent and to maintain its culture. Employee Benefit Trust (EBT): A more flexible trust that can be used to hold shares for distribution to specific employees or groups, or to hold shares to satisfy future share options. 2. Benefits to Employees and Families Long-Term Value Creation: Employees benefit from the growth of the company, often receiving dividends or bonuses (up to £3,600 per year per employee, tax-free in the UK, if qualifying conditions are met). No Direct Cost: Employees generally do not have to pay for the shares themselves; the trust holds them on their behalf. Security and Stability: EOTs help in preserving the company's independence and preventing a hostile takeover. Incentivisation: A share in the company’s success acts as a strong motivator for employee engagement and retention. 3. Advantages for the CEO Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Exemption: In the UK, if a controlling interest (more than 50%) is sold to an EOT, the seller can benefit from a 0% capital gains tax rate. Succession Planning: It provides a clean, tax-efficient exit strategy, allowing the CEO to leave behind a stable company. Legacy Preservation: The trust structure keeps the company intact, ensuring the legacy of the founder and the company’s culture continues. 4. Key Considerations and Risks Valuation Requirements: The shares must be sold to the EOT at their full market value, which requires an independent valuation. Funding the Trust: Because the trust often lacks funds, it is common for the seller (CEO) to be paid via a "vendor loan note," where the company uses future profits to pay for the shares over several years. Complex Rules: As of the Autumn Budget 2024, there are stricter rules for EOTs, including limitations on former owners controlling the trust and new residency requirements for trustees. Employee Performance Connection: In a 100% employee-owned company, it can be difficult to differentiate incentives for senior staff compared to the rest of the employees. Real-World Examples John Lewis Partnership: The classic example of a "John Lewis model," where all employees are beneficiaries of the trust. Richer Sounds: The founder transferred controlling ownership to an EOT to reward employees and secure the future. Boosst Financial Planning: The founders sold 100% of their shares to an EOT to protect the

No Direct Cost: Employees generally do not have to pay for the shares themselves; the trust holds them on their behalf. Security and Stability: EOTs help in preserving the company's independence and preventing a hostile takeover. Incentivisation: A share in the company’s success acts as a strong motivator for employee engagement and retention. 3. Advantages for the CEO Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Exemption: In the UK, if a controlling interest (more than 50%) is sold to an EOT, the seller can benefit from a 0% capital gains tax rate. Succession Planning: It provides a clean, tax-efficient exit strategy, allowing the CEO to leave behind a stable company. Legacy Preservation: The trust structure keeps the company intact, ensuring the legacy of the founder and the company’s culture continues. 4. Key Considerations and Risks Valuation Requirements: The shares must be sold to the EOT at their full market value, which requires an independent valuation. Funding the Trust: Because the trust often lacks funds, it is common for the seller (CEO) to be paid via a "vendor loan note," where the company uses future profits to pay for the shares over several years. Complex Rules: As of the Autumn Budget 2024, there are stricter rules for EOTs, including limitations on former owners controlling the trust and new residency requirements for trustees. Employee Performance Connection: In a 100% employee-owned company, it can be difficult to differentiate incentives for senior staff compared to the rest of the employees. Real-World Examples John Lewis Partnership: The classic example of a "John Lewis model," where all employees are beneficiaries of the trust. Richer Sounds: The founder transferred controlling ownership to an EOT to reward employees and secure the future. Boosst Financial Planning: The founders sold 100% of their shares to an EOT to protect the

Severe Financial Distress - The company was unable to meet its liabilities as they fell due. - Cashflow pressures were significant due to high capital expenditure and operating costs typical of compute‑intensive infrastructure businesses. 2. Asset‑Heavy Business Model - The company invested heavily in specialised computing hardware and data‑centre equipment. - These assets depreciated quickly and required substantial ongoing energy and hosting costs. 3. Funding & Market Conditions - The company had been backed by the UK Government’s Future Fund, indicating it relied on external investment to scale. - Market volatility in energy‑intensive computing (including HPC and blockchain‑adjacent workloads) likely contributed to instability. What the Administrators Did (Across All Reports) 1. Secured and Realised Assets The administrators: - Took control of the company’s data‑centre equipment, servers, and related infrastructure. - Marketed and sold assets where possible to generate returns for creditors. - Managed contracts, leases, and any recoverable receivables. data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Lake Parime Ltd went into administration in early 2023, with Ed Boyle and Will Wright appointed as joint administrators, meaning leadership changed from its original directors, who included founder Sath Ganesarajah, CEO Alexander Siedes, Creative Director John Davies, and COO Nimesh Mistry (who joined from Barclays). Key Individuals & Roles (Before Administration): Sath Ganesarajah: Founder. Alexander Siedes: CEO & Board Member. Nimesh Mistry: COO, joined from Barclays. John Davies: Creative Director. Paul Shepherdson: Business Development Director. Current Status: Administration: The company entered administration in January 2023, with Interpath Advisory handling the process. Company Name Change: The entity is now listed as LP REALISATIONS LIMITED, with its registered office address updated in February 2023. In Summary: While specific directors led Lake Parime, the company's operations were taken over by administrators, leading to significant changes in its structure and management, as reflected in its filing history.

data.author: Mollusk
data.content: It's one thing to be 'pre-revenue', but when the future revenue streams are not established (see Korean Permits etc.) there are big questions. The company would need to bring forward proof of future revenue potential to justify any increase in (or even current) share price.  If new streams need to be found in Gold Mining opportunities, any delay means more and more capital will be required in a bullish gold market.  What should have been a positive (gold price rising) could be a major problem.  Until something concrete comes through I think it might be best to sit on the sidelines and watch.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Bluebird Executive Director and Interim CEO Aidan Bishop said, "I am very pleased with the progress of discussions in the Philippines which are looking very positive and will enable, if successfully completed, Bluebird to maintain an ongoing exposure with zero future cash commitments. On a personal level, I embarked some time ago on a journey to understand and learn about bitcoin. I am convinced that we are witnessing a tectonic shift in global markets and that bitcoin will reshape the landscape of financial markets on every level. By adopting a 'gold plus a digital gold' strategy, it offers the Company an opportunity to turn the page and look to the future and seek to attract a new type of shareholder. Under the leadership of a new CEO, once identified, it is my sincere hope that Bluebird will finally realise its ambitions for which it was initially established for." Sath Ganesarajah, 43, British Sath is a seasoned entrepreneur and investor with deep expertise in crypto assets and institutional capital markets. He first bought Bitcoin in 2017 and has since advised several global hedge funds and institutional investors on crypto strategy, digital asset fund structuring, and large-scale infrastructure deployment-supporting mandates totaling over US$1 billion in Assets Under Management (AUM). He is the founder and CEO of The BE Company, a clean energy and AI infrastructure business with operations in the UK, US, and Canada. Across multiple ventures, he has developed and operated over 50MW of digital infrastructure, including immersion-cooled compute and modular clean energy projects.  Earlier in his career, Sath held senior trading and structuring roles at Morgan Stanley, Citi, and Credit Suisse, specialising in structured credit and emerging markets. The Board will work together with a view to expediting the appointment of a new CEO by the end of July with several candidates presently in the frame whom will be tasked with spearheading Bluebird's UK first approach of physical Gold + "digital gold" investing strategy. Mr Ganesarajah commented:  "Bluebird has the right ingredients-hard assets, public market access, and a clean slate. My ambition is to help shape Bluebird into a £1 billion company over the coming cycle."

data.content: Venture capital firms have already become more selective with crypto investments as the market matures. Investment decisions now focus on scalable, sustainable projects rather than speculative ventures, according to industry sources. Farley believes surviving companies must transition from being "features" to becoming "institutional, compliant, and respected." The shift represents a move away from what he described as "chasing frog coins and 100x use" toward more substantial on-chain finance. Even traditional financial institutions like the NYSE have shown interest in blockchain systems for stock trading, suggesting the underlying technology has staying power despite individual project failures. This institutional endorsement indicates blockchain infrastructure is becoming a fixture of modern global finance.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Crypto faces immediate industry consolidation as market downturn exposes weak business models, according to Bullish CEO Tom Farley. Bitcoin's 45% decline from its October 2025 peak of $126,100 to approximately $69,400 is accelerating a shakeout that should have occurred years earlier. Farley, who previously served as president of the New York Stock Exchange, told CNBC that inflated valuations kept unrealistic expectations alive until now. "The same thing is going to happen starting right now in crypto," Farley said during his Friday interview. He witnessed similar consolidation patterns in the exchange sector during his NYSE tenure. Companies with $10 million in revenue and no growth were still demanding $200 million valuations, according to Farley. That era of over-optimistic pricing is ending as the market correction washes away what he called "false optimism." "People are going to realize they don't have businesses, they have products, and they need to merge up, and they need to scale, and that is going to happen," Farley said. The consolidation should have started one to two years ago but was delayed by unrealistic 2020-era valuation expectations. The process will involve larger companies acquiring smaller, underperforming projects across the crypto market. This absorption will likely lead to significant layoffs, internal reorganizations, and industry-wide restructuring. Venture capital firms have already become more selective with crypto investments as the market matures. Investment decisions now focus on scalable, sustainable projects rather than speculative ventures, according to industry sources. Farley believes surviving companies must transition from being "features" to becoming "institutional, compliant, and respected." The shift represents a move away from what he described as "chasing frog coins and 100x use" toward more substantial on-chain finance. Even traditional financial institutions like the NYSE have shown interest in blockchain systems for stock trading, suggesting the underlying technology has staying power despite individual project failures. This institutional endorsement indicates blockchain infrastructure is becoming a fixture of modern global finance. The current market downturn acts as a filter, forcing companies to prove long-term viability to attract buyers or survive independently. The result will likely be a crypto industry that resembles traditional finance, with a handful of large, heavily regulated companies providing most infrastructure. For firms that adapt during this transition, consolidation offers a chance to become legitimate long-term players in what Farley sees as an increasingly professional global market. The transformation marks the end of what he characterized as the industry's "wild west" phase. Bullish CEO Tom Farley says crypto faces immediate industry consolidation - Originally published on Technobez

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: BMV Blue Print Gold Reserve • Streaming contracts and physical holdings secure permanence. • Land & infrastructure assets strengthen the balance sheet with recurring lease income. • Collateral strength provides downside resilience and credit efficiency. The Bridge • Gold provides permanence; bitcoin provides progress. • Together, they create a treasury that is both resilient and compounding. Bitcoin Rail • All inflows systematically converted into bitcoin under custody. • Enhances liquidity, settlement, and compounding power. • Complements gold, never replaces it. Capital Structure Advantage • Equity trades as a clean bitcoin proxy. • Gold is ring-fenced for creditors, reducing financing costs. • Dual-asset symmetry ensures balance across cycles. The Treasury Flywheel The Flywheel turns capital into contracts, contracts into bitcoin, and bitcoin into shareholder value — quarter after quarter. Why Streaming Wins Contract-backed: predictable inflows, enforceable terms. Capital-light: exposure without operational drag. Scalable: multiple counterparties without consolidation risk. NAV-accretive: uplift recorded at signing, compounded through treasury conversion. Gold streaming secures permanence. Bitcoin streaming drives growth. Together, they power the Reserve & Rail model.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: That's why he has bought in one of the best Metals derivative players in the world - Frank Amato The timing of BMV's plan seems to be on point ! Since the Company's Operational Update on 10 December 2025, BMV has experienced a marked increase in inbound interest relating to its gold streaming and treasury strategy. This includes engagement from counterparties exploring tokenised and digitally settled gold structures, as well as institutional and strategic participants seeking exposure through structured upstream arrangements spanning physical metal, derivative-linked flows, and tokenised formats. The Board believes this renewed interest reflects a broader crossover between digital asset infrastructure and physical gold, alongside evolving macro conditions. In particular, the Company notes the current interest-rate outlook and the potential rollback of certain US trade tariffs as factors that may act as catalysts for renewed risk appetite, providing structural tailwinds for gold-linked treasury and streaming strategies. The Board continues to believe that BMV's gold streaming and treasury model is well positioned to capture this demand in a disciplined and regulated manner.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: The convergence of gold streaming/mining and Bitcoin treasury strategies has emerged as a significant trend, with companies aiming to blend the "old safe haven" (physical gold) with "digital gold" (Bitcoin) to diversify reserves and hedge against inflation. This "hybrid" approach is gaining traction among resource developers and investment firms, particularly in the UK and through major stablecoin issuers. Key Players and Developments (As of early 2026): Tether: The stablecoin giant has aggressively moved into this space, holding over $300 million in gold royalty stocks by late 2025, including stakes in Elemental Altus Royalties, Versamet Royalties, and Metalla Royalty & Streaming. Tether also holds substantial gold reserves, with estimates reaching 80–116 metric tonnes, often utilizing its digital gold product XAUT. Bluebird Mining Ventures Ltd: A key player merging these strategies, Bluebird is a gold development company that has recently focused on "marrying its existing mining projects and expertise with the future that is 'digital gold' aka bitcoin". They are working on gold-streaming projects in Asia and Africa while investing in Bitcoin mining. Mendell Helium PLC: This company announced it is adopting a bitcoin treasury management policy and plans to use a loan facility secured by its bitcoin holdings to finance the acquisition of the Pick Lake deposit in Ontario, illustrating a direct link between bitcoin holdings and physical asset acquisition. Tap Global Group [LON:TAP]: Launched a "Bitcoin Treasury as a Service" (BTaaS) to help publicly listed companies, particularly in the UK, manage Bitcoin as a core treasury asset, with a focus on institutional-grade security for companies merging digital assets into their strategies. B HODL: A UK-based firm that has established a position as a Bitcoin treasury company, focusing on accumulating Bitcoin while also operating Lightning Network operations. Strategy and Market Context: "Digital Gold" Adoption: Similar to the MicroStrategy playbook, these companies often seek to hold Bitcoin as a long-term strategic reserve rather than for immediate cash flow, positioning themselves as future-focused. Diversification: The trend represents a move to diversify treasury holdings beyond just fiat currency, using both gold (for traditional stability) and Bitcoin (for high growth/digital scarcity). Funding Mechanism: Some companies are using Bitcoin loans to fund the acquisition of traditional physical mining assets. Market Position: As of early 2026, the strategy is facing volatility, with some Bitcoin treasury firms seeing their market capitalization drop below the value of their actual Bitcoin holdings. Gold and Bitcoin Correlation: Data from late 2025/early 2026 shows a 0.14 correlation between Bitcoin and gold, indicating that while they are often paired in portfolios, they can move independently. However, both are increasingly viewed as "debasement trades"—methods to protect against fiat c
data.thread_title: RE: Institutional-grade deployment in gold streaming

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Components of Institutional Deployment Upfront Financing: A significant, often upfront payment is made to the miner in exchange for a percentage of future production at a fixed, discounted price. Operational Control: While streaming companies do not operate the mines, they may place restrictions or covenants on the operator to protect the investment. Long-Term Focus: Institutions often hold these positions for over three years as part of a long-term strategy to gain exposure to gold while avoiding the high capital expenditures and operational risks of direct mining. Institutional Players The market is dominated by large players like Franco-Nevada, Royal Gold, and Sandstorm, alongside major institutional investors seeking to add "safer" gold exposure compared to direct equity. BlueBird are using Bitcoin in what is a 1 off unique Treasury platform - The reason why it must have taken so long for the prospectus to be approved by the FCA due to it's complex nature - legal and compliance etc! The balance sheet is now in a healthy and robust position with cash at hand and in trust - maybe this financial moving around was not a bad thing after all - I have a feeling in my waters that this will surprise many here as to what can transpire Shrewdie

Structure: These agreements often act as non-dilutive financing for miners, allowing them to monetize by-product gold without giving up equity. Transparency and Compliance: These investments must meet high standards of transparency, with auditing, and legal, and regulatory compliance. data.author: Nowthewiser
data.content: @Frankie963 , on this proposed Employee Ownership Trust (EOT), the first question is: where is the funding coming from? If the plan relies on issuing more shares, that simply dilutes existing shareholders to create a structure that seems to benefit the directors rather than the owners. This is not how an investable company behaves. Before introducing schemes like this, the CEO should be able to demonstrate a real product and a credible business model. Right now, all we see are constant restructurings, no cash, no delivery, and endless promises. In my opinion, the pattern is starting to resemble a well‑constructed Ponzi‑style setup, where new shareholder money is needed just to keep the story alive. Based on my own experience and losses, I cannot recommend anyone put their money into this.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: Several major companies associated with billionaire fortunes have at least 50% of their shares or voting rights held in trusts, foundations, or family-controlled holding companies. These structures are often used to ensure long-term control, manage succession, and handle philanthropic donations. Tata Sons (Tata Group): The promoter holding company of the Tata Group, which controls companies like Tata Motors and Tata Steel, has approximately 50% or more of its share capital held by two trusts: Sir Dorabji Tata Trust and Sir Ratan Tata Trust. Roche Group: Descendants of the founding Hoffmann and Oeri families hold slightly more than 50% of the voting shares in this Swiss healthcare giant. Robert Bosch GmbH: The German automotive supplier and industrial giant has 92% of its share capital held by Robert Bosch Stiftung GmbH (a charitable foundation). Cargill Inc.: The world's largest privately held company is owned by the Cargill and MacMillan families, who hold roughly 85% of the company, often managed through family trusts. Auchan Group: The French retailing group is controlled by the Mulliez family, who hold roughly 95% of the company. Louis Dreyfus Company: The agricultural commodity company is primarily owned by the Louis-Dreyfus family, who hold approximately 96% of the company. Mars Incorporated: The candy and pet food conglomerate is 100% owned by the Mars family, with management of ownership often tied to trusts. Aldi Group: The Albrecht family controls 100% of the Aldi retail group, split between trusts. Key Takeaways regarding Trust Ownership: Legal Structure: A trust often holds legal ownership of shares for the benefit of family members (beneficiaries). Control vs. Equity: In some cases, such as Roche, the trust may control over 50% of the votes, while holding less than 10% of the total capital. Philanthropic Trusts: Billionaires, including Bill Gates (via the Gates Foundation Trust) and Warren Buffett, use trusts to manage large blocks of company stock (like Berkshire Hathaway) for philanthropic purposes.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: A CEO leaving a considerable amount of shares in a trust for employees and their families is typically structured as an Employee Ownership Trust (EOT) or an Employee Benefit Trust (EBT). This strategy allows the CEO to transition ownership while providing, rewarding, and incentivising staff, often with significant tax advantages. Here is an analysis of this approach based on current practices and regulations: 1. Structure of the Trust Employee Ownership Trust (EOT): A type of EBT where the trust holds a controlling stake (more than 50%) in the company on behalf of all employees. It is often used to ensure the company remains independent and to maintain its culture. Employee Benefit Trust (EBT): A more flexible trust that can be used to hold shares for distribution to specific employees or groups, or to hold shares to satisfy future share options. 2. Benefits to Employees and Families Long-Term Value Creation: Employees benefit from the growth of the company, often receiving dividends or bonuses (up to £3,600 per year per employee, tax-free in the UK, if qualifying conditions are met). No Direct Cost: Employees generally do not have to pay for the shares themselves; the trust holds them on their behalf. Security and Stability: EOTs help in preserving the company's independence and preventing a hostile takeover. Incentivisation: A share in the company’s success acts as a strong motivator for employee engagement and retention. 3. Advantages for the CEO Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Exemption: In the UK, if a controlling interest (more than 50%) is sold to an EOT, the seller can benefit from a 0% capital gains tax rate. Succession Planning: It provides a clean, tax-efficient exit strategy, allowing the CEO to leave behind a stable company. Legacy Preservation: The trust structure keeps the company intact, ensuring the legacy of the founder and the company’s culture continues. 4. Key Considerations and Risks Valuation Requirements: The shares must be sold to the EOT at their full market value, which requires an independent valuation. Funding the Trust: Because the trust often lacks funds, it is common for the seller (CEO) to be paid via a "vendor loan note," where the company uses future profits to pay for the shares over several years. Complex Rules: As of the Autumn Budget 2024, there are stricter rules for EOTs, including limitations on former owners controlling the trust and new residency requirements for trustees. Employee Performance Connection: In a 100% employee-owned company, it can be difficult to differentiate incentives for senior staff compared to the rest of the employees. Real-World Examples John Lewis Partnership: The classic example of a "John Lewis model," where all employees are beneficiaries of the trust. Richer Sounds: The founder transferred controlling ownership to an EOT to reward employees and secure the future. data.author: Frankie963
data.content: Several major companies associated with billionaire fortunes have at least 50% of their shares or voting rights held in trusts, foundations, or family-controlled holding companies. These structures are often used to ensure long-term control, manage succession, and handle philanthropic donations. Tata Sons (Tata Group): The promoter holding company of the Tata Group, which controls companies like Tata Motors and Tata Steel, has approximately 50% or more of its share capital held by two trusts: Sir Dorabji Tata Trust and Sir Ratan Tata Trust. Roche Group: Descendants of the founding Hoffmann and Oeri families hold slightly more than 50% of the voting shares in this Swiss healthcare giant. Robert Bosch GmbH: The German automotive supplier and industrial giant has 92% of its share capital held by Robert Bosch Stiftung GmbH (a charitable foundation). Cargill Inc.: The world's largest privately held company is owned by the Cargill and MacMillan families, who hold roughly 85% of the company, often managed through family trusts. Auchan Group: The French retailing group is controlled by the Mulliez family, who hold roughly 95% of the company. Louis Dreyfus Company: The agricultural commodity company is primarily owned by the Louis-Dreyfus family, who hold approximately 96% of the company. Mars Incorporated: The candy and pet food conglomerate is 100% owned by the Mars family, with management of ownership often tied to trusts. Aldi Group: The Albrecht family controls 100% of the Aldi retail group, split between trusts. Key Takeaways regarding Trust Ownership: Legal Structure: A trust often holds legal ownership of shares for the benefit of family members (beneficiaries). Control vs. Equity: In some cases, such as Roche, the trust may control over 50% of the votes, while holding less than 10% of the total capital. Philanthropic Trusts: Billionaires, including Bill Gates (via the Gates Foundation Trust) and Warren Buffett, use trusts to manage large blocks of company stock (like Berkshire Hathaway) for philanthropic purposes.

data.author: Frankie963
data.content: A CEO leaving a considerable amount of shares in a trust for employees and their families is typically structured as an Employee Ownership Trust (EOT) or an Employee Benefit Trust (EBT). This strategy allows the CEO to transition ownership while providing, rewarding, and incentivising staff, often with significant tax advantages. Here is an analysis of this approach based on current practices and regulations: 1. Structure of the Trust Employee Ownership Trust (EOT): A type of EBT where the trust holds a controlling stake (more than 50%) in the company on behalf of all employees. It is often used to ensure the company remains independent and to maintain its culture. Employee Benefit Trust (EBT): A more flexible trust that can be used to hold shares for distribution to specific employees or groups, or to hold shares to satisfy future share options. 2. Benefits to Employees and Families Long-Term Value Creation: Employees benefit from the growth of the company, often receiving dividends or bonuses (up to £3,600 per year per employee, tax-free in the UK, if qualifying conditions are met). No Direct Cost: Employees generally do not have to pay for the shares themselves; the trust holds them on their behalf. Security and Stability: EOTs help in preserving the company's independence and preventing a hostile takeover. Incentivisation: A share in the company’s success acts as a strong motivator for employee engagement and retention. 3. Advantages for the CEO Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Exemption: In the UK, if a controlling interest (more than 50%) is sold to an EOT, the seller can benefit from a 0% capital gains tax rate. Succession Planning: It provides a clean, tax-efficient exit strategy, allowing the CEO to leave behind a stable company. Legacy Preservation: The trust structure keeps the company intact, ensuring the legacy of the founder and the company’s culture continues. 4. Key Considerations and Risks Valuation Requirements: The shares must be sold to the EOT at their full market value, which requires an independent valuation. Funding the Trust: Because the trust often lacks funds, it is common for the seller (CEO) to be paid via a "vendor loan note," where the company uses future profits to pay for the shares over several years. Complex Rules: As of the Autumn Budget 2024, there are stricter rules for EOTs, including limitations on former owners controlling the trust and new residency requirements for trustees. Employee Performance Connection: In a 100% employee-owned company, it can be difficult to differentiate incentives for senior staff compared to the rest of the employees. Real-World Examples John Lewis Partnership: The classic example of a "John Lewis model," where all employees are beneficiaries of the trust. Richer Sounds: The founder transferred controlling ownership to an EOT to reward employees and secure the future. Boosst Financial Planning: The founders sold 100% of their shares to an EOT to protect the

data.author: Nowthewiser
data.content: Would like to Add to Shrewed_mole Combined Summary of All Administrator Reports (2024–2025) 🏢 Company Background • 	Name: LP Realisations Limited (formerly Lake Parime Limited) • 	Company No.: 11773819 • 	Sector: High‑performance computing, data‑centre infrastructure, and IT hardware • 	Administrators: Interpath Advisory • 	Administration Start: 2023 • 	Dissolution Process Initiated: January  2025 Why the Company Entered Administration Across the filings, the administrators outline a consistent picture: 1. Severe Financial Distress - The company was unable to meet its liabilities as they fell due. - Cashflow pressures were significant due to high capital expenditure and operating costs typical of compute‑intensive infrastructure businesses. 2. Asset‑Heavy Business Model - The company invested heavily in specialised computing hardware and data‑centre equipment. - These assets depreciated quickly and required substantial ongoing energy and hosting costs. 3. Funding & Market Conditions - The company had been backed by the UK Government’s Future Fund, indicating it relied on external investment to scale. - Market volatility in energy‑intensive computing (including HPC and blockchain‑adjacent workloads) likely contributed to instability. What the Administrators Did (Across All Reports) 1. Secured and Realised Assets The administrators: - Took control of the company’s data‑centre equipment, servers, and related infrastructure. - Marketed and sold assets where possible to generate returns for creditors. - Managed contracts, leases, and any recoverable receivables. Investigated Company Affairs Standard statutory investigations were carried out, including: • 	Director conduct • 	Transactions prior to insolvency • 	Creditor claims • 	Contractual obligations No unusual or exceptional findings are mentioned in the filings. Managed Creditor Claims - Preferential, secured, and unsecured creditor classes were identified. - Claims were reviewed and adjudicated. - The reports indicate limited returns for unsecured creditors due to the company’s asset profile. 💷 Financial Outcome (High‑Level) While the filings contain detailed numbers, the combined picture is: - Asset realisations were modest relative to liabilities. - Secured creditors received the majority of recoveries. - Unsecured creditors are expected to receive little or no dividend. - The company had no viable route to rescue, leading to dissolution. 🏁 Final Stage: Move to Dissolution (Jan 2025) The final filing — Notice of Move from Administration to Dissolution — confirms: - The administration has achieved its statutory purpose. - No further asset realisations are expected. - The company will be dissolved after the notice period. - This marks the end of the insolvency process. 📚 Sources - Companies House filing history for LP Realisations Limited, including: - Administrator’s Pr

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Lake Parime Ltd went into administration in early 2023, with Ed Boyle and Will Wright appointed as joint administrators, meaning leadership changed from its original directors, who included founder Sath Ganesarajah, CEO Alexander Siedes, Creative Director John Davies, and COO Nimesh Mistry (who joined from Barclays). Key Individuals & Roles (Before Administration): Sath Ganesarajah: Founder. Alexander Siedes: CEO & Board Member. Nimesh Mistry: COO, joined from Barclays. John Davies: Creative Director. Paul Shepherdson: Business Development Director. Current Status: Administration: The company entered administration in January 2023, with Interpath Advisory handling the process. Company Name Change: The entity is now listed as LP REALISATIONS LIMITED, with its registered office address updated in February 2023. In Summary: While specific directors led Lake Parime, the company's operations were taken over by administrators, leading to significant changes in its structure and management, as reflected in its filing history.

data.author: Mollusk
data.content: It's one thing to be 'pre-revenue', but when the future revenue streams are not established (see Korean Permits etc.) there are big questions. The company would need to bring forward proof of future revenue potential to justify any increase in (or even current) share price.  If new streams need to be found in Gold Mining opportunities, any delay means more and more capital will be required in a bullish gold market.  What should have been a positive (gold price rising) could be a major problem.  Until something concrete comes through I think it might be best to sit on the sidelines and watch.

data.author: shrewed_mole
data.content: Bluebird Executive Director and Interim CEO Aidan Bishop said, "I am very pleased with the progress of discussions in the Philippines which are looking very positive and will enable, if successfully completed, Bluebird to maintain an ongoing exposure with zero future cash commitments. On a personal level, I embarked some time ago on a journey to understand and learn about bitcoin. I am convinced that we are witnessing a tectonic shift in global markets and that bitcoin will reshape the landscape of financial markets on every level. By adopting a 'gold plus a digital gold' strategy, it offers the Company an opportunity to turn the page and look to the future and seek to attract a new type of shareholder. Under the leadership of a new CEO, once identified, it is my sincere hope that Bluebird will finally realise its ambitions for which it was initially established for." Sath Ganesarajah, 43, British Sath is a seasoned entrepreneur and investor with deep expertise in crypto assets and institutional capital markets. He first bought Bitcoin in 2017 and has since advised several global hedge funds and institutional investors on crypto strategy, digital asset fund structuring, and large-scale infrastructure deployment-supporting mandates totaling over US$1 billion in Assets Under Management (AUM). He is the founder and CEO of The BE Company, a clean energy and AI infrastructure business with operations in the UK, US, and Canada. Across multiple ventures, he has developed and operated over 50MW of digital infrastructure, including immersion-cooled compute and modular clean energy projects.  Earlier in his career, Sath held senior trading and structuring roles at Morgan Stanley, Citi, and Credit Suisse, specialising in structured credit and emerging markets. The Board will work together with a view to expediting the appointment of a new CEO by the end of July with several candidates presently in the frame whom will be tasked with spearheading Bluebird's UK first approach of physical Gold + "digital gold" investing strategy. Mr Ganesarajah commented:  "Bluebird has the right ingredients-hard assets, public market access, and a clean slate. My ambition is to help shape Bluebird into a £1 billion company over the coming cycle."
